responses.content: For the first quarter, our worldwide net sales were $127.4 billion, up 9% year-over-year, or 11% excluding approximately 210 basis points of unfavorable impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. This was above the top end of our guidance range.

The uncertain economic environment and ongoing inflationary pressures continue to drive cautious spending across consumers. Customers are looking to stretch their budgets further, focusing on value, which has led to moderated spending on discretionary categories and shifts to lower-priced items while maintaining healthy demand in everyday essentials.

Third-party sellers comprised 59% of overall unit sales in Q1, up from 55% one year ago. Advertising revenues grew 23% year-over-year, driven by strong engagement in our advertising services, particularly sponsored product and brand offerings.

AWS net sales were $21.4 billion in the first quarter, up 16% year-over-year, representing an annualized sales run rate of more than $85 billion. Customers continue to optimize their cloud spending in response to economic conditions, with Q2 revenue growth rates expected to be about 500 basis points lower than Q1.

We reported $4.8 billion in operating income for the first quarter, above the top end of our guidance range. This was negatively impacted by an estimated employee severance charge of approximately $470 million in Q1, including $270 million related to AWS.
We reported overall net income of $3.2 billion in the first quarter, which includes a pretax valuation loss of $467 million from our investment in Rivian Automotive.

Our operating cash flow for the trailing 12 months ended March 31st increased to $54.3 billion, up 38% year-over-year. For the full year 2023, we expect capital investments to be lower than our $59 billion investment level in 2022, primarily driven by a decrease in fulfillment network investments while continuing to invest in AWS infrastructure supporting Large Language Models and generative AI.
Our primary focus is on reducing our cost to serve within our operations network while continuing to invest in long-term strategic areas that enhance customer experiences.

We redesigned our fulfillment network from a national to a regionalized model, creating 8 interconnected regions. This has resulted in shorter travel distances, lower cost to serve, and faster delivery speeds. We are on track to achieve our fastest Prime delivery speeds ever in 2023.

Our advertising services continue to grow robustly, driven by our substantial investment in machine learning to ensure relevant ads for customers. We are also expanding our advertising efforts into video, live sports, audio, and grocery properties.

AWS continues to grow with a strong new customer pipeline. We are focusing on helping customers optimize their AWS spend to navigate the uncertain economy, building long-term relationships and a sustainable business.

We have streamlined our investments to focus on areas with high potential impact, including streaming entertainment, low Earth orbit satellites with Kuiper, and healthcare. We remain committed to investing in these strategic areas to drive long-term growth.

Prime offers exceptional value through a combination of entertainment, fast shipping, music, gaming, and other benefits. We continue to enhance Prime to drive member engagement and increase wallet share.

responses.topic: Future of AWS and Generative AI
responses.content: We are heavily investing in Large Language Models and generative AI, believing that these technologies will transform customer experiences. Our recent announcements on foundational models and machine learning chips position AWS as a leader in this space.

We are making significant progress in improving operational efficiency across our fulfillment network and stores business. Our regionalization efforts and process improvements are expected to enhance our operating margins beyond pre-pandemic levels.
Our international e-commerce footprint continues to grow robustly, with strong customer acquisition and adoption of Prime benefits in over 10 new countries added in the last five years.

Our grocery business, including Whole Foods and Amazon Fresh, continues to grow. We are experimenting with new formats and strategies to optimize our physical store footprint and enhance our grocery offerings.

We remain optimistic about our strategic investments in healthcare, Kuiper, and other emerging areas. These investments are aimed at transforming customer experiences and driving long-term growth for Amazon.

questions: Andy, can you talk about the degree to which optimization has been done in AWS versus what you think could still lie ahead, and when do you start to lap some of those efforts?

On the CapEx side, I think you said overall CapEx would be down in ‘23. Can you just help us understand that a little bit better between retail and AWS? And then what’s required on CapEx from a generative AI and large language model perspective?

Andy, you’ve talked about driving greater levels of efficiencies in the Company and possibly returning to some of the margin structures we saw pre-pandemic. Can you give us an update on where you think you are in those efforts to match margins versus pre-pandemic levels and balance profitability with growth initiatives over the next couple of years?

Andy, you talked a lot about the long-term AI and large language model potential out of AWS. Could you walk us through 2 or 3 key points of differentiation that you think AWS offers in AI tools versus competitors?
Regarding Echo and Alexa, how do you think about the key investment priorities going forward, and what’s your view on ROIC around that division?
Can you add more color on the acceleration in the International segment, both in top line and margin?
On the physical stores and grocery strategy, can you provide any updates on optimizing stores across categories and any changes to footprint plans for those businesses?
AWS, can you call out any unusual items in April or Q2 for the comparable quarter? I know you had a very good Q2 last year.

Andy, you mentioned investments in medical and Kuiper in the shareholder letter. Why those areas, and does the Company ever think about breaking out all the big investments for more clarity on the retail margin structure?
